data.text: How Do You Transport Your Camera Equipment When Biking or Travelling?
When bikepacking or traveling how you transporting your camera equipment? What type of bags using and what photo equipment fits?
Oveja Negra waist pack with XT2 and 23mm prime
data.author: Nick Mandeville

data.text: GoPro , it‚Äôs a lot easier to carry
data.author: Adrian Cozlea

data.text: yes its comfortable, but for the purposes i use, i need carry much more heavy equipment
data.author: Andrius Sazanskis

data.text: Good luck in your travels. Post some of the pictures please so we can enjoy them too ü§óüçª
data.author: Adrian Cozlea

data.text: some folks like a real camera. The photos even from a phone look like crap when viewed on anything besides Instagram and don't handle processing. I get most people don't care but if you grew up shooting slide film you expect more, that's where those of us still exist. The struggle is real.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: , you can get good images out of a phone *if you know what you are doing*. Though not so good for action pics or dingy lighting. I have plenty of 'real' cameras, but still use a phone for some work.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: images are fine you can compose and make use of good light in most circumstances. The files suck. I feel like I have some experience. I've been a photographer for ~30 years. Shot AHL hockey and minor league baseball all-star games. Cyclecross and MTB, Div 1 collegiate athletics including soccer, tennis, track, among other sports over the years. I'm not trying to big time you, I'm just pointing out I have some clue as to image quality. But phone files just plain suck and gopro stills aren't much better. I always shoot raw (DNG) +DRO (jpeg) on my phone to get the best files for both immediate Instagram use and archival/edit use. But if you plan to do anything besides low res web work, you are going to struggle with a phone. For me the minimum is a decent digital compact in RAW. Besides that phones are just awkward to work with when a camera has physical dials and menus that make sense. OpenCamera is the best cellphone camera I've used.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: , I'm a pro photographer and a camera is just a tool. Sometimes a MF 100MP camera is the best tool and sometimes an iPhone is. Different cameras also have different looks and feel to final image and will influence how you work. I shot *very* differently with each kind of camera and that's a good thing. | also have no problem with lo-fi images, they can often make for far nicer photos than a technically better quality image. Apple did a series of huge grainey B+W images taken on iPhones to promote them years back. They were stunning. Too many folk obsess about technical quality but can't take an interesting photo to save their lives.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: I went with my touring Ortlieb Ultimate 6 bag. It doesnt look great with a bikepacking setup but I have not been able to find anything better when it comes to camera equipment. My mirrorless Sony A7 and a 24-70 2.8 and a 70-200/4 fits in there.
data.author: Lars Bengtsson

data.text: I‚Äôm done carrying a big camera, now using a point and shoot waterproof camera and it‚Äôs awesome, I end up taking more pictures too because its easy and fast to use, I keep it accessible in my top tube bag
data.author: Guillaume Dougados

data.text: Olympus OMD5.2 with a pancake or small prime lens (and maybe the 40-150 plastic zoom packed elsewhere). Smallish, powerful, weatherproof*, lots of great glass available if you want more. 4s handheld no problem due to the stabilisation, saves carrying a tripod unless you're into timelapse or astro. I pack it either in large top-tube fuel-pod with extra padding at base or a backpack. I have a theory that a prime lenses may be more resilient than zooms, fewer moving parts, less worry about vibration - my 25mm seems fine after a lot of miles. * bodies are weather proof, but only the heavier (amazing) pro lenses are.
data.author: Geraint Mandrake

data.text: - exceptional cameras for bad weather conditions. Seen folk leave them under a running shower for testing and one chap lost his in the snow, found it several months later after snow melted. Worked fine.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: I have an Olympus EM5 MK3 with a 12-100 F4 lens that I carry inside a fanny bag: Think Tank Turnstyle 10 V1. Prior to that, with two prime lenses, I also used a fanny bag -that one made out of Cordura-, and couldn't be happier with it and the system overall. Easy and quick access, less bumping as it remains attached to the body -not to the bike-, and conveniently protected from the rain used under the Goretex jacket when needed (use of a thin Vaude drybag is of extra help).
data.author: Gerard Castell√†

data.text: Pack NW Ridgeline Roll Top hip pack.
data.author: Kimberly Much

data.text: Total noob to bikepacking but I was looking into the same thing. I am giving this a try. Its pretty well padded, has velcro wall panels, and slides on and off really easy.
data.author: Mark Grunwald

data.text: vibrations on a rack are hell if you are off road. Be careful. I'd pad it with open and closed cell foam.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: thanks for the tip. I plan to do most traveling on the road or gravel. I will keep that in mind though.
data.author: Mark Grunwald

data.text: still pad it if doing gravel unless it's smooth dirt class 1. Racks are the same as putting a camera in the top tube bag. It will get wrecked on rough rides, and the roads around me are worse than my class 1 dirt/gravel.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: If I took my good kit out, it would go in a fanny pack/backpack. I'm using an old GF2 I had kept it in my top tube bag when it has the 14mm or 35mm f1.4/1.8 on it. but I have some additional foam under it (on the tube) which probably saved it for now. I didn't think about the vibrations killing it. Worse I've kept lenses in my frame bag but in padded cases.. But my usual setup keeps everything in a handlebar bag where it semi floats. Everything is in padded cases or wraps. I don't shoot anything I care much about from the bike. My M4/3 lens system is high quality but it's a toy to me. It's my old pentax 35mm manual focus glass (mostly m42 screw mount) which is absolutely beautiful but nothing I use on my digital pentax (except for fun) and some newer manual focus native M4/3 lenses. Results are nice but if it all got trashed in a wreck I'd only cry for a minute.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: Carry it on your person in a backpack or fanny pack. The vibration isn‚Äôt good for your camera. At least on your person the vibration is less as well as the big hits if off road.

data.text: I did that for years. I finally settled on a photo vest.
data.author: Tim Attwood

data.text: I was just going to throw my camera in my panniers and I was only going to carry my 35mm lens with me. But I may reconsider, although my next route is mainly on road.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: I'm exploring all this too - a good handlebar bag is the ultimate as you have easy one handed access to shoot... although ultimately something on your body will be the best for reducing camera shake on your gear.
data.author: Paul Daley

data.text: You really need a good reason to carry a camera other then your phone camera. Plus you can access maps and other data with your phone. And if you must‚Ä¶ Make a phone call‚Ä¶..
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: redundancy. Having all your eggs in one basket seems like a bad idea. Photos, nav, communications hinging on one single non removable memory card (in most phones now) and no interchangeable battery, which means, a single USB (or whatever Apple uses these days) port to keep your photos, nav and coms running. Worse, often sat comm runs through your phone now. So using even more battery. I still use an old Android 4.3 device for my route nav with OSMand it had removable batteries. When they die i hot swap them. And I'm on my way. With the screen off I can ride most/if not all day. Turning it on only if I'm unsure or want to verify. No, for me, I'll keep my phone for grab shots, backup nav and communications. A separate camera for the bulk of the photos and separate nav for the bulk of nav. Redundancy is the spice of life.
data.author: Justin Serpico
